Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: The main protest march is beginning in a few minutes, and you are needed at the front to lead the first chant.
Story: I stood at the corner, my heart pounding as the protest crowd gathered behind me, waiting for my signal to begin the march. My phone buzzed with messages from the organizing team—everyone was counting on me to lead the first chant, to set the tone for the whole demonstration. Just as I took a deep breath, ready to step forward, I caught sight of my stepbrother, Jamie, across the street. He was distracted, headphones in, about to step off the curb without looking. My stomach twisted. I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he was safe, especially since Mom had asked me to keep an eye on him today. But the protest was about to start, and everyone was watching me, waiting. I felt torn in two, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding something I couldn’t give to the other. My feet felt rooted to the spot as I wrestled with what to do next.
